prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for throwing an unwanted party?
So next week is my best friend's birthday and i decided to throw him a surprise party. Everyone was excited and everything was cool untill today.

We talked today just us 2, and i asked him what he is doing for his bday, he said that if said that hes glad theres no party and if there was one he would be mad af. (The party is at his house so hes just gonna be extra mad)

He said he hates birthday parties many times before but i thought he was just saying that so hr won't be dissapointed if theres no party.

Ive been planning this party for a long time and its way too late to cancel. 

AITA for not listening to him and doing whatever i want?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The person is asking if they're in the wrong for throwing a surprise party for their best friend despite the friend not wanting one. The friend clearly said he's glad there's no party and would be mad if there was one. The party is at his house too, so he's in a position to be really upset.

The user thought the friend was just saying that to avoid disappointment, but the friend actually hates birthday parties. The user planned it for a long time and it's too late to cancel. So the question is, is the user in the wrong?

Well, the friend had already expressed multiple times that he hates parties. Even if the user thought he was just saying that, it's still a clear indication. The user should have respected the friend's wishes. Throwing a party despite knowing the dislike seems inconsiderate. The fact that the party is at his house makes it even worse because it's his space and he's being forced into a situation he really dislikes. 

Even though the user put effort into planning, that's not a valid excuse if they ignored the friend's clear preferences. The key here is respecting the friend's boundaries. So yeah, the user is in the wrong. Answer A.
